item.title: Fanatical Movember Charity Bundle Packs In Rogue Trader and More for Just $12
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/fanatical-movember-charity-bundle

Fanatical has a new charity bundle up for grabs, and for just $12 (or more if you choose), you'll get a ton of pretty big games and support the Movember charity initiative into the bargain.

The Movember Game 'Stache Charity Bundle is, per Fanatical, "the first bundle to join the Movember mustache movement", and it's got a whopping 15 games to offer, including Owlcat's well-received CRPG Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader.

Other games you'll get as part of this bundle include truckin' sim American Truck Simulator, city-builder SteamWorld Build, and goopy action-adventure game The Gunk, among several others.

There's no Humble-style tier system here, either; paying $12 gets you all 15 games on the list, so you don't have to worry about any hidden costs stopping you from getting all the games in the bundle.

Additionally, 100% of the proceeds go to the Movember charity initiative, so you don't need to choose how much you want to go to Fanatical itself; you're supporting Movember all the way if you pick this one up.

Here's a full list of the games available as part of the Fanatical Movember Game 'Stache Charity Bundle. All of these games activate via Steam, and many of them are either Playable or Verified on Steam Deck as well.

  • SteamWorld Build
  • Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader
  • The Gunk
  • American Truck Simulator
  • Chivalry 2
  • The Escapists
  • Doors: Paradox
  • Panzer Corps 2
  • Hello Neighbor
  • For the King
  • Inertial Drift
  • Isonzo - Movember Handlbar DLC (base game not included)
  • Filthy Animals Heist Simulator
  • Eastside Hockey Manager
  • The Corridor
  • The Little Acre

If you're unaware of the work Movember does, it's essentially a charity set up to help men with their mental and physical health. It's principally focused on three areas: mental health and suicide prevention, prostate cancer, and testicular cancer.

You can read more about the work Movember does right here. The Fanatical Movember Game 'Stache charity bundle, meanwhile, is available here.

item.title: Remedy's Revenue Is Up as Alan Wake 2 Inches Towards Profitability
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/remedy-q3-financials-alan-wake-2

Alan Wake 2 and Control developer Remedy has announced its financial results for the third quarter of its fiscal year, and things are looking a little rosier for the Finnish studio.

In Remedy's financial report, the studio says its revenue has jumped 128.6% over the same period from the previous year. Between July and September this year, Remedy raked in €17.9 million in revenue, and its operating profit was €2.4 million, up from a €5.5 million loss in Q3 2023.

The studio also says that while Alan Wake 2 still isn't profitable, the game had recouped "most of its development and marketing expenses" by the end of the quarter, which means that it may well be profitable within the next couple of quarters.

According to Remedy, full production on Control 2 is scheduled to start in 2025, with the sequel currently progressing "well in the production readiness stage". Many of the game's "critical features" have been implemented, Remedy says, and it's currently testing "workflows and pipelines" for full production.

Similarly, the upcoming Max Payne remakes are "making steady progress", and Remedy says it's "gradually reaching important milestones" in development on the projects.

For the rest of 2024, Remedy expects its revenue to "increase from the previous year", and it also expects its "operating profit to improve", so it looks like Remedy will likely have a better time in 2024 than in 2023.

The report also looks ahead to Remedy's upcoming projects, including the aforementioned Control 2 and the recently-revealed FBC: Firebreak, a multiplayer Control spinoff set to launch sometime next year.

While Remedy is teaming up with Annapurna (even amidst that company's recent turmoil) for Control 2, the Finnish developer will be self-publishing the game, as it will with FBC: Firebreak.

Here's hoping Remedy's fortunes continue to improve in the coming months. Stay tuned for more on all things Remedy-related.
